H0.text: They get energy from living organisms, as observed with some sea grasses growing near a group of palm trees on a sandy shore.

H1.text: They turn decaying matter into nutrients, a role performed by both the sea grasses growing near the group of palm trees on the sandy shore.

H2.text: They provide food for other organisms that grow near a group of palm trees on a sandy shore.

H3.text: They absorb oxygen from the environment, which is the role of both the palm trees and sea grasses that grow near each other on a sandy shore.

A4.text: The main source of such energy is sunlight, but a minute fraction of primary production is driven by lithotrophic organisms, using the chemical energy of inorganic molecules.

A5.text: Like all autotrophic plants, seagrasses photosynthesize, in the submerged photic zone, and most occur in shallow and sheltered coastal waters anchored in sand or mud bottoms.

A6.text: Seagrass meadows provide food and habitat for many marine species.
